comment.shortText: Indicates whether the job is live or test, useful for filtering jobs in dashboard.
Job can be in one particular state at any given time.
comment.text:
Note: not all states are necessarily supported by underlying mechanism. For example,
3-D Secure handling is not supported by `LocalRobot` so local jobs will never be in `AWAITING_TDS` state.

comment.shortText: Cloud job instance reflects the Job created in Automation Cloud.
comment.text:
When the job is created it is automatically tracked, which results in mirroring the
state of the remote jobs and emitting appropriate lifecycle events when outputs are emitted,
inputs are requested, job finishes successfully, job fails, etc.

The exact job state is not guaranteed to be precise due to polling delays and network latencies.

Note: cloud jobs are not subject to the concurrency limitations described in `LocalJob` because
Automation Cloud will run them in isolated runners.

With `CloudRobot` it is also possible to resume tracking existing jobs using `robot.getJob` method.

comment.shortText: Job constructor should not be used directly; use `robot.createJob()` to run the scripts.
Job constructor should not be used directly; use `robot.createJob()` to run the scripts.

The `jobId` of the AutomationCloud job. Can be used to resume tracking of existing job
using `const job = await robot.getJob(jobId)`.
comment.text: Note: this method is Cloud-only, so the job instance must be cast to `CloudJob` to access `jobId`.

comment.shortText:
The `jobId` of the AutomationCloud job. Can be used to resume tracking of existing job
using `const job = await robot.getJob(jobId)`.
comment.text: Note: this method is Cloud-only, so the job instance must be cast to `CloudJob` to access `jobId`.

comment.shortText: Cancels the remote Job which results in `JobCancelled` error (if the job was still running).
Subscribes to `output` event for all output keys.
comment.text: When any output is emitted by script, the handler `fn` is invoked.
handler callback, can be either synchronous or asynchronous

comment.shortText:
Subscribes to `awaitingInput` event for specified input key and optionally fulfills
the input request with data returned by handler funciton.
comment.text:
When input with specified `key` is requested by script, the supplied `fn` handler is invoked.

Unless the handler returns `undefined`, the result value is sent as input data for that key,
fulfilling the input request.

Use this to handle deferred inputs.
requested input key, `*` to receive all events.

handler callback, can be either synchronous or asynchronous; the return value is
 submitted as input data for specified input `key`

Resolves when all outputs with specified `keys` are available.
The output data is returned as an array in the same order as specified keys.

ProTipâ„¢ Use destructuring to access the data:

```
const [products, deliveryOptions] = await job.waitForOutputs('products', 'deliveryOptions');
```
output keys

comment.shortText:
Robot API used to execute automations remotely on Automation Cloud
and track their lifecycle events using HTTP polling.
comment.text:
When the job is created the POST request is send to Automation Cloud,
which results in a new job being created. It is also possible to resume an existing job
using `robot.getJob(jobId)`, provided that `jobId` is known.

A `CloudRobot` instance is scoped to a single service (which represents a Script in Automation Cloud)
and can be used to create multiple jobs with the same configuration.
For creating jobs that execute different scripts, separate CloudRobot instances should be created.

comment.shortText: Robot instance configuration.
Provides access to Automation Cloud Vault functionality.

Creates a new job which conceptually results in starting an automation
and starts tracking its lifecycle events (i.e. emitted outputs, requested inputs, success,
failures, etc.)
comment.text:
The exact behaviour depends on the underlying mechanism:

- `LocalRobot` will run a provided script using the embedded `Engine`
  connected to a local Chromium instance;
- `CloudRobot` submits a new job to Automation Cloud API and starts tracking it
  by polling its state.

The job is automatically tracked after creation. The tracking stops after the job
reaches one of the final states (`success`, `fail`). For this reason it is recommended
that `await job.waitForCompletion()` is always included to prevent dangling promises
and unhandled promise rejections.

Please refer to specific implementations for more details.
Job initilalization parameters (includes `category` and `input`).

comment.shortText: Resumes the tracking of the job that was previously created.

comment.text: can be obtained from `CloudJob` instance.

comment.shortText:
Cloud-only API: queries Automation Cloud for outputs that were previously emitted
for this service, optionally matching specified `inputs`.

comment.text: output key
optionally filter the results by matching specified inputs

comment.shortText: An error with formalized code and optional details.
Unified interface for running Autopilot scripts.
comment.text:
This class has two standard implementations:

- {@link LocalJob} runs the job using local Autopilot Engine and Chromium browser
  and tracks its progress by subscribing to script lifecycle events.
- {@link CloudJob} submits the job to Automation Cloud and tracks its progress
  Automation Cloud API.

The job should be created via {@link Robot.createJob}.

comment.shortText:
Instructs the underlying mechanism to cancel the job.
This also causes `waitForCompletion` promise to reject with `JobCancelled` error.
comment.text: Note: the job is not guaranteed to get interrupted immediately.

comment.shortText:
If job is waiting for input (i.e. due to input request by script and not yet submitted),
then this method returns the requested input key, otherwise `null` is returned.
If job has failed, returns the information about the error.
comment.text: Note: error info is not an `Error` instance â€” do not `throw` it.

Retrieves the data of an output with specified `key` if it was already emitted.
Returns `undefined` if output does not exist.

comment.shortText: Resolves whenever job finishes successfully. Rejects if job fails.
comment.text: Your code should always `await job.waitForCompletion()` to avoid dangling promises.

comment.shortText: LocalJob represents the state of the locally running automation.
comment.text:
Each job sets up a new `Engine` instance which manages the connection to Chromium browser,
alongside all the state associated with running a script.

Note: running multiple jobs in parallel on the same Chromium browser is technically possible,
but can be a subject to various limitations:

 - scripts gain an access to an entire browser instance, not just some specific tabs,
   so jobs can interfere with each other, depending on functionality being used by both
   (for example, it is possible for a script to close all the tabs, therefore preventing other
   job from executing normally)
 - Chrome can put inactive tabs to background process, which can cause some issues (for example,
   some users reported not being able to execute JavaScript)
 - when taking screenshots or changing emulation settings the tab needs to be activated; this can also
   cause problems with adjacent jobs executed in parallel.

comment.shortText:
A Robot instance which is used to execute a particular script
with embedded Engine using local Chromium instance.

Creates a new job which conceptually results in starting an automation
and starts tracking its lifecycle events (i.e. emitted outputs, requested inputs, success,
failures, etc.)
comment.text:
The exact behaviour depends on the underlying mechanism:

- `LocalRobot` will run a provided script using the embedded `Engine`
  connected to a local Chromium instance;
- `CloudRobot` submits a new job to Automation Cloud API and starts tracking it
  by polling its state.

The job is automatically tracked after creation. The tracking stops after the job
reaches one of the final states (`success`, `fail`). For this reason it is recommended
that `await job.waitForCompletion()` is always included to prevent dangling promises
and unhandled promise rejections.

Please refer to specific implementations for more details.
Job initilalization parameters (includes `category` and `input`).

comment.shortText: A Robot instance which is used to execute a particular script.
comment.text:
Robot instance is scoped to a script or service and can be used
to create multiple jobs with the same configuration.
For creating jobs that execute different scripts, separate Robot instances should be created.

comment.shortText:
Creates a new job which conceptually results in starting an automation
and starts tracking its lifecycle events (i.e. emitted outputs, requested inputs, success,
failures, etc.)
comment.text:
The exact behaviour depends on the underlying mechanism:

- `LocalRobot` will run a provided script using the embedded `Engine`
  connected to a local Chromium instance;
- `CloudRobot` submits a new job to Automation Cloud API and starts tracking it
  by polling its state.

The job is automatically tracked after creation. The tracking stops after the job
reaches one of the final states (`success`, `fail`). For this reason it is recommended
that `await job.waitForCompletion()` is always included to prevent dangling promises
and unhandled promise rejections.

Please refer to specific implementations for more details.
Job initilalization parameters (includes `category` and `input`).

comment.shortText: Vault is used to store sensitive information like payment card number (PAN).
comment.text:
The typical usage involves:

- obtaining a one-time password: `const otp = await robot.vault.createOtp()`
- putting the card number into the vault: `const panToken = await robot.vault.createPanToken(pan, otp)`;
- using the obtained token as part of Job input

comment.shortText: Creates one time password (OTP) which can subsequently be used to put data to vault.

Exchanges payment card number (PAN) to a pan token which can be safely passed around
(i.e. used as part of inputs).
comment.text: If `otp` is not provided, it will be automatically created.

comment.shortText: Constructs a payment iframe URL hosted by Automation Cloud Vault.
comment.text: See https://docs.automationcloud.net/docs/vaulting-payment-card for more information
one-time password, must be obtained via `await robot.vault.createOtp()`
iframe customization options, see {@link PaymentIframeOptions} for more info

comment.shortText: Optional CloudRobot configuration parameters.
Poll interval in milliseconds for job state synchronization. Default: `1000` (1 second).
Required CloudRobot configuration parameters.
Automation Cloud authentication parameters.
A UUID of the Service to be executed (you can obtain it from Automation Cloud dashboard).
Describes the reason of job failure.
A designation of the root cause of error:
comment.text:
- `client` indicates the class of errors that involve client actions
  (e.g. invalid inputs supplied, job cancelled, etc.)
- `server` indicates platform-related failure (e.g. worker crash, timeout, API unavailable, etc.)
- `website` indicates a known limitation with the website (e.g. an unsupported feature, flow or layout)

comment.shortText: Error code in PascalCase, typically constrained by schema.
Arbitrary details for logging and debugging.
comment.text: Note: implementations should never depend on the structure of this object.

comment.shortText: If applicable, human-readable message for logging and debugging.
comment.text: Note: implementations should never depend on the structure of this string.

comment.shortText: Job initialization parameters, provided when the job is being created using `robot.createJob()`.
Job category, used for filtering jobs in Automation Cloud dashboard.
Initial job inputs (provided as objects).
Job inputs are the primary means of supplying data to automations.
comment.text: Data is supplied by client in key-value format. Keys must be in camelCase.

comment.shortText: Describes initial job inputs in object representation.
Describes initial job inputs in object representation.
Job outputs are the primary means of receiving data from automations.
comment.text: Data is emitted by script in key-value format. Keys must be in camelCase.

comment.shortText: Optional configuration parameters for local robot.
Specifies whether the jobs will be run automatically after they are created. Default: `true`.
An array with additional arguments used to launch Chromium. Default: `[]`.

Indicates whether `--headless` command line parameter will be used to launch Chromium.
Default: `false`.

Local path to Chromium executable.
Default is taken from `CHROME_PATH` environment variable.

Chrome CDP port, as specified in `--remote-debugging-port` command line parameter.
Default: `9123`

Whether to close the active tab after the job is finished.
Leaving the tab open can be handy for debugging, but not so much for automating on scale.
Default: `true`.
Whether to close all existing tabs after the job is finished. Default: `false`.

The duration in milliseconds of waiting for the requested input before failing the job
with `InputTimeout` error. Default: `60000` (1 minute).
Standard logging interface, compatible with `console`.
comment.text:
Use this interface to provide your own logging system to Robot
(either directly or via an adapter).
```

comment.shortText:
Additional configuration of secure payment iframe.
See https://docs.automationcloud.net/docs/vaulting-payment-card for more info.
If specifies, restrict the choice of card brands.
comment.text: Default: `['visa', 'mastercard', 'amex', 'discover']`

comment.shortText: The CSS to use. Default: `https://vault.automationcloud.net/forms/index.css`

If specified, restricts the rendered fields.
Additionally, field labels and placeholders can be customized as per
https://docs.automationcloud.net/docs/vaulting-payment-card#customised-label-and-placeholder
comment.text: Default: `['pan', 'name', 'expiry-select', 'cvv']`

comment.shortText: The URL of payment iframe. Default: `https://vault.automationcloud.net/forms/index.html`
If specified, the "name" form field will be pre-filled with specified value.

If enabled, the iframe will emit validation events for each field using `vault.validation` messages.
See https://docs.automationcloud.net/docs/vaulting-payment-card#validateoninput-optional for more info.
comment.text: Default: `false`

comment.shortText:
Automation Cloud Authentication. Use `string` form for legacy authentication (aka "client secret key"),
otherwise provide the OAuth2 details as an object (you can obtain them by creating a new Application in
Automation Cloud dashboard).
Cloud robot configuration, consists of required and optional parameters.

Event subscription methods like `onOutput` return handlers which can subsequently be invoked
with zero arguments to unsubscribe from the event.

Local robot configuration, includes mandatory `script` which can be
either a path to local file containing a script created an Autopilot, or the JSON object
representing the serialized script.
